awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Non- and Semi-Parametric Modeling of Structured Human Activity Patterns Using Point Processes
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will advance theory and methods for analyzing structured human-activity data. Because of recent technological advances, large amounts of real-time human-activity data, such as social media data and transaction data, are being collected by various sources. The complexity and magnitude of these new data call for new statistical modeling tools. The methods to be developed in this project are motivated by and can be used to further understanding of human behaviors. Through active interdisciplinary collaborations with domain experts, the project will establish a bridge between the statistics community and the behavioral finance and social science communities. Open-source R packages will be developed and made available for public use through CRAN. Key materials from the project will be incorporated into the advanced graduate student courses.

The investigators will develop a series of new non- and semi-parametric point process models for temporal point patterns of structured human activities. In particular, they will develop (1) a multi-level functional principal component analysis framework for modeling human activities such as stock trading etc.; (2) a simultaneous modeling and clustering approach for daily human activity patterns that are not only structured but also heterogeneous across different sub-populations; and (3) a new class of bivariate point process models to model the complex behaviors of modern social media users and provide meaningful insights into a user's content generating behavior. For the first two aims, popular functional data analysis tools will be introduced to model point processes with complex structures. Efficient computational algorithms will be developed and theoretical properties of these algorithms will be investigated. For the third aim, a semi-parametric regime-switching multi-type point process model will be used to model social media posting behaviors, where the posting intensity functions are approximated with spline basis functions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Abundant high-resolution human activity point pattern data have been made available from various venues such as stock markets, social networks, and online retailers. The complexity and magnitude of these new data call for new innovative statistical modeling tools. The main focus of this research project was to develop a series of new nonparametric and semi-parametric point process models for real-time temporal point patterns of structured human activities and to advance the frontiers of theory and methods for analyzing such data.

 

The outcomes of this project involve research on two types of point pattern data: (1) repeatedly observed temporal point processes; and (2) spatial point processes. Specifically, 

1. The proposed methodology in our Aim I has been completed and the results have been published in the Journal of Machine Learning Research (a top journal in machine learning research).

2. The proposed research in our Aim II has been completed and the results have been accepted for publication in the Thirty-fifth Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems (NeurIPS 2021, a top peer-reviewed conference in machine learning research).

3. The proposed methodology in our Aim III has been completed and the results have been submitted to the Journal of Business & Economic Statistics (a top journal in Statistics/Economics).

4. Other results derived from the Aims I-III have also been published in leading Statistics and Machine Learning journals, such as the Journal of the American Statistical Association.

 

For repeatedly observed temporal point processes, the PIs have developed a series of statistical tools such as the functional principal component analysis, an expectation-solution algorithm for clustering structured temporal point process data, and a novel parametric model for the complex data generating mechanism of event time data collected from various social media platforms. The proposed models are useful additions to the existing toolbox for analyzing such data, and their numerical, as well as statistical properties, have been rigorously investigated in our work. The second line of research outcomes involves studies of spatial point pattern data, for which the PIs have built several novel statistical models. The usefulness of these models is demonstrated through applications to the street crime activity data in Washington DC. For example, the PIs have developed a multinomial logistic regression model that can be used to make valid statistical inferences for six types of crime activities ( robbery, theft from automobile, motor vehicle theft, assault with weapon, burglary, and other theft). Several graphical tools are developed to predict the likelihood of occurrences of different types of crimes. These tools can be used by the police department to better allocate their resources throughout the city. The PIs have also developed a semiparametric goodness-of-fit test for spatial point process models without imposing restrictive model assumptions, which is demonstrated to be useful for analyzing crime activity data. The PIs would like to emphasize that the proposed methodologies are suitable for a wide range of applications in many disciplines such as social sciences and economics, and are extremely easy to use.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2021
Modified by: Ganggang Xu
